7. Well, in 2013 they did it again...only through the Supreme Court. Shelby v Holder made federal oversight of elections in certain areas historically known for voter suppression, to be unconstitutional. The reason? ""We're not racist anymore."" But what happened? Voter ID laws everywhere!
6. Because of the repealing of the Enforcement Act in 1894, elections wouldn't be subjected to federal oversight for another 70 years with the passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act. So where are we?

5. However twenty years later in 1894, Congress repealed the federal oversight sections of the 1870 Force Act. Most people credit 1896 Homer v Plessy as moment that marked Jim Crow, but I'd argue that repealing two years earlier allowed for the crafting of new restrictive state constitutions

4. Also the 1965 Voting Rights Act technically wasn't ""new"" legislation either. After the passage of the 15th Amendment in 1870 (which gave Black men the right to vote), it was the 1870-71 Enforcement Bills (also known as the KKK Act) that gave it teeth. 3. Same thing goes with the 1965 Voting Rights Act. It's often narrated as the single most significant & effective piece of civil rights legislation in American history. And they have been trying to weaken it ever since. But it's not been easy

2. The 1964 Civil Rights Act was not technically a ""new"" law, it was a restoration of the rights repealed in 1883 that were the product of the 1875 Civil Rights Act introduced by Senator Charles Sumner. It essentially passed because Sumner had died the year before. It was gone in 8 years

Its really cool to see one research community finally stand up against bad-faith actors within the research community!
I admit to being thrilled that Vaccine is publishing papers that are timely and relevant enough to make the news at Science. doi.org/10.1016/j.va...

I‚Äôm not talking about the made-up ‚ÄúGold Standard‚Äù but the actual standard used by actual scientists: the strength of the evidence, as assessed by expert review. MAHA anti-vax pseudoscience cannot meet this standard. But every paper published in Vaccine must.

Vaccination is under ideological attack, particularly in the US. Vaccine and health disinformation is ubiquitous and overwhelming, both in the US and abroad. One way to fight back that we all already embrace as a professional community is with science done to the highest standard

Because we come from such broad backgrounds, often our opinions diverge or we lack consensus. We are scientists, so we are critical. We are human, so we are complex. But we are united by one thing: we follow the evidence where it leads, with the scientific method as our guide.

Vaccine serves the entire vaccine research community & covers everything vaccination, from basic science to policy to safety to $$$ to clinical trials. We are a diverse, global community & that is one of our strengths.

I will always be grateful for opportunities to emphasize the integrity of our editorial & peer review practices & to invite authors to submit their work‚Äîespecially if it contributes to a larger scientific debate or has a major impact on our field, public health, or society.

Last November, the FDA‚Äôs top vaccine regulator forced FDA scientists to withdraw a paper because it showed that COVID vaccines work for all ages. Several papers published in Vaccine have been cited selectively by RFK Jr to mislead the public about vaccines. Now Vaccine is in the news again.

Have I ever mentioned how surreal it is to be an Editor-in-Chief of a journal called Vaccine right now? www.science.org/content/arti... It‚Äôs pretty wild, at least by typical academic journal editorial office standards.

Fewer beat reporters. Fewer people with time to sit on a story for six months until the truth cracks open. Truth requires labor. And labor costs money. And when labor disappears, ‚Äúcontent‚Äù replaces journalism.

When a place like that starts shedding huge portions of staff, it‚Äôs not just a business story. It‚Äôs a signal that tells every other newsroom what the future might look like. Fewer investigative teams.

You don‚Äôt have to burn down the press if you can make it too weak to fight back. The layoffs at the Post matter symbolically because it‚Äôs not just any newsroom. It‚Äôs one of the last global legacy institutions with deep investigative muscle memory.
They destabilize it. They fracture it. They hollow it out and make it economically fragile, culturally distrusted, and structurally dependent on the very power centers it‚Äôs supposed to watchdog.

And I need people to understand something uncomfortable: authoritarian systems don‚Äôt usually begin by banning journalism outright. That‚Äôs messy. That creates martyrs and triggers resistance. What they do instead is starve journalism.

Private clinics can provide necessary treatment in addition to the expensive fluff that nobody needs. However, as wellness culture gets increasingly mainstream, the avenues for health care scams are widening. This is especially problematic alongside the rise of virtual care, as I wrote about here:

This isn't necessarily a marker of better care, but it does mean that the discourse on menopause and its stark deficiencies in knowledge/treatment have gotten loud enough to attract wider medical interest. Is this largely profit-motivated interest? Definitely, but that doesn't mean it's all grift.

This model of private clinic isn't new. It's based on bundling private pay services & publicly funded MD care and selling the whole package as a premium product. These clinics pop up alongside trending health care issues, eg: ADHD clinics. What's new here is that menopause care has made the cut.
